Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamic Rational Inattention: Theory and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Models of rational inattention have proved to be useful in understanding many economic phenomena, such as price and investment stickiness, asymmetric response of consumption to income shocks, and coordination failure. The proposed research will provide a new tool to analyze and interpret these - as well as other issues that pertain to economic agents' limitations on the ability to process information - via a new class of dynamic rational inattention models that have a recursive form. The key component in these models is an Infinite Horizon Attention Constraint (IHAC), which captures the intertemporal trade-off in acquiring information. An IHAC specifies what type of information is affordable today, and how the choice of what to learn today affects the possible choices of information tomorrow and in the future. The IHAC is universal in a well-defined sense and yet it - as well as all the other parameters of the model, such as state dependent utilities and the anticipated evolution of beliefs over states - can be uniquely identified from choice behavior.

First, the proposed research will characterize axiomatically the types of behavior that can be described by the model. Second, it will develop applications of the model that generate new theoretical predictions, both in the realm of individual decision making and in the context of strategic interactions, and in different areas, ranging from macro-economic phenomena to the explanation of evidence collected by psychologists and economists in laboratory experiments. For example, the model can capture notions such as expertise and fatigue in acquiring information and gives rise to new behavioral phenomena such as familiarity bias. It will also generate new insights about policies that might ameliorate inefficient attention choices. The relevance of this issue is underscored by the current debate about the role exhausted attention seems to play in trapping people in poverty (see Mani et. al. 2013 and Mullainathan and Shafir, 2013).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of the award is a manuscript titled ``Subjective Information Choice Processes'' that has been submitted for publication and is currently under review.  Following the goals outlined when submitted the proposal, in this paper we propose a new class of dynamic models that capture subjective (and hence unobservable) constraints on the amount of information a decision maker can acquire, pay attention to, or absorb, via an Information Choice Process (ICP). An ICP specifies the information that can be acquired about the payoff-relevant state in the current period, and how this choice affects what can be learned in the future. Our aim was to address the following two questions: (1) Can (unobservable) information constraints be identified from the decision maker’s preferences and what type of data is needed to achieve this identification? And (2) What types of observable choice behavior can be rationalized by unobservable information choices? Our main contribution is showing that the constraint imposed by the ICP is identified up to a dynamic extension of Blackwell’s famous notion of informativeness. All the other parameters of the model are also uniquely identified. Additionally, we provide behavioral foundations, ie axioms, for the model. In terms of its broader impact, we show that the model can generate many plausible behavioral patterns, some of which are inconsistent with the ``standard’’ model used in the literature, and demonstrate its applicability via numerous examples. These applications will be valuable in many different areas, ranging from macro-economic phenomena to the explanation of evidence collected by psychologists and economists in laboratory experiments, and all the way through to the analysis of policies whose effect depends on the subjective information constraints the economic agent in question is facing.
